STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 23, 2020
Latoya Harvey
Child and Family Charities
4287 Five Oaks Drive
Lansing, MI 48911
RE: License #: CB330201039
Child and Family Charities
4287 Five Oaks Drive
Lansing, MI 48911
Dear Ms. Harvey:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
07/16/20. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB330201039
Licensee Name: Child and Family Charities
Licensee Address: 4287 Five Oaks Drive
Lansing, MI 48911
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 882-4000
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Julie Thomasma, Designee
Name of Facility: Child and Family Charities
Facility Address: 4287 Five Oaks Drive
Lansing, MI 48911
Facility Telephone #: (517) 882-4000
Original Issuance Date: 10/07/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
CONTRACT-FOSTER CARE
CONTRACT-ADOPTION
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
2(d) Two of eight new employee files contained undated references.
3(a) One of three existing employee files reviewed contained an annual performance
evaluation that was completed late.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of four applicable licensing files reviewed sent the application out less than 60
days prior to the expiration date of the license.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
4

(1) One of six licensing files reviewed contained a reevaluation report completed
late.
(2)(d) Four of six licensing files reviewed did not document compliance with
practicing emergency procedures in the reevaluation report. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must
report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this
into compliance.
(8) Two of four applicable licensing files submitted licensing recommendations less
than 15 days prior to the expiration of the foster home license. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19 and
Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The agency must
report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this
into compliance.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of a child in the home.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(a) One of three borrowed bed files reviewed was found to have approval dated after
the child was placed in the home.
(b) Three of three borrowed bed files contained initial home studies with approvals
after the child was placed in the home.
(c) One of one applicable borrowed bed file contained a reevaluation report
endorsed after the child was placed in the home. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19 and Renewal Report,
08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The agency must report on why
the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
R 400.12328 Foster home record.
(2) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(a) All documents pertaining to certification of the home.
5

Two of two closed licensing files reviewed were not in compliance as one file did not
have closing documents. The other file contained documentation that the license
was closed after expiration and did not contain the request by the foster parents to
close out the license.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
5 of 8 applicable files reviewed were noncompliant with signatures:
 Four of six applicable files were missing parent signatures, and/or had late
parent signatures, and/or did have a PATP.
 Four of eight foster care files were found to be missing caregiver signatures
(licensed foster parent, unlicensed relative, residential placement) or had late
caregiver signatures.
 One of one applicable foster care file was missing the older youth signatures.
Three of three independent living files reviewed had missing or late youth
signatures.
 Three of eight foster care files and three of three independent living files
reviewed, had plans that were approved by the supervisor late (past the 14
days permitted in policy). It is also notable that several plans were approved
in MiSACWIS timely, but not signed for a long period after; in one case is was
about five months after the MiSACWIS approval.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP,
11/13/19 and Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The
agency must report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to
bring this into compliance.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) All of the following child characteristics:
(i) Gender.
(ii) Race.
(iii) Height and weight.
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
(v) Identifying marks.
(vi) Religious preference.
(vii) School status, including grade, last school attended,
and educational program.
6

(b) Name, known addresses and marital status of the child’s
parents or legal guardian, if any.
(c) Names, ages, and known addresses of any siblings.
(d) Known names, addresses, and dates of any previous out-of-
home placements.
(e) The date that the agency received the child for placement.
(f) The child’s legal status and the agency’s legal right to provide
care.
(g) Documentation of the child’s placement preparation.
Two of seven applicable foster care files reviewed did not contain a placement
outline that documents the required information. Another two files did not document
the height (length) of those children. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report,
10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19 and Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and
corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The agency must report on why the previous
CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason why
return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s age,
appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer guardian
ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the change,
except when prior notification would jeopardize the child’s care
or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the agency shall
notify the foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior
notice was not given.
7

(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning the
change in placement.
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
Four of six applicable foster care files reviewed were found to have missing and/or
late DHHS 69 Action Summaries for documentation of the noted requirements. In
two of these cases, there was not documentation of proper notification to all parties
of the move.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
Three of five applicable foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that
the required information was provided to, or provided timely, to the caregivers at the
time of placement. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and
corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must report on why the previous
CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
8

and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
(2)(a) Two of five applicable foster care files contained late initial service plans. It is
notable that the total number of later reports was lower (for both initial and updated)
and the length overdue was decreased to 2 days and 9 days for these two identified
later initial service plans. This indicates the current CAP is working. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The
agency must report on why the previous CAPs have failed and how they plan
to bring this into compliance.
(3) One applicable foster care file did not have a 30-day modified service plan.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits
are detrimental to either child.
One of two applicable foster care files reviewed did not document all sibling visits.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP,
11/13/19 and Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The
agency must report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to
bring this into compliance.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
Three of eight foster care files did not contain DHHS 69 Action Summaries to
document the case closing as required. Another one did not document that all
required information was provided to the youth. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19 and Renewal Report,
08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The agency must report on why
the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
9

One of two applicable independent living files reviewed did not document that the
program statement was provided to the youth. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must report
on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into
compliance.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of two applicable independent living files reviewed did not document that the
policies and procedures were provided to the youth. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must
report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this
into compliance.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
Two of two applicable independent living files reviewed did not document the
rationale for selection of independent living as most appropriate.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
(c) Provide the youth with a telephone number to contact the
agency on a 24-hour, 7-days-a-week basis.
10

(b) Two of five independent living files reviewed did not document all monthly review
of managing expenditures (budget). It is notable that several were during the
phone/video contacts with the youth during the COVID -19 crisis. Workers
documented in several case contacts that the budget was not done with the youth
due to not meeting face to face. This should have still been completed with the youth
over the phone/video meeting.
(c) One of two applicable independent living files did not document that the youth
was provided the 24/7 telephone number.
Both sections are a REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and
corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must report on why the previous
CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth ha biological children, the service plan
must address the living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth’s biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
Three of three independent living files reviewed were found to have late case service
plans.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Three of three independent living files reviewed did not contain all required updated
contracts. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding
CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must report on why the previous CAP have failed
and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
R 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each youth who
ends independent living is provided with all of the following:
11

(a) Basic information about health, housing,
counseling/mental health services, and emergency resources.
One of two closed independent living files did not document on the DHHS 69 that
medical information was provided to the youth at case closing.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of four adoptive family evaluations were not completed in 90 days. One was
completed by the worker but not approved by the supervisor until three months later.
The other file contained an evaluation done 11 months late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.30 - Page 27 – Supervisory Oversight
Three of eight foster care files were found to be missing documentation of monthly
supervision for worker and supervisor. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report,
10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19. The agency must report on why
the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into
compliance.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722.03 page 14-16 Placement exception request (PER)
Two of three applicable foster care files reviewed for sibling splits were found to
have missing or late PERs for sibling splits. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19 and Renewal Report,
08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The agency must report on why
the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring this into
compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-05 Case Documentation: MDHHS and PAFC providers
must maintain all case documentation in the child's electronic case record
in MiSACWIS.
12

Several files were found to have documentation that was not uploaded to
MiSACWIS as required. MiSACWIS is the file of record for the State and all case
related documentation must be entered and uploaded timely.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – page 11-13 Medical Passports
Seven of eight foster care files and two of three independent living files were found
to have missing, and/or late, and/or unsigned medical passports. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP, 11/13/19 and
Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18. The agency
must report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they plan to bring
this into compliance.
DHHS Policy - FOM 801 - Page 4 – Dental Examination Schedule
One of two applicable foster care files contained a late annual dental exam.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H - Page 10 – CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH
PARENT(S)/ GUARDIAN(S)
Two of five applicable foster care files reviewed did not document all required
parental contacts.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H Page 1-3 – OVERVIEW and QUALITY VISIT
STANDARDS
Five of eight foster care files did not always document sufficient quality visit
standards. Several social work contacts were observed to only state that the home
visit occurred.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H p 15 TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER
CONTACTS
Three of eight foster care files reviewed were found to have untimely entry of social
work contacts that were between 10 and 48 days late. Although this is a repeat
violation, it is notable that the number of files with late entries is down from six to
three. Two of these three files only had isolated occurrences of untimely entries,
which is observed to be a significant improvement from the last inspection and
indication that the current CAP is working but may just need some modification.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP,
11/13/19 and Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18.
The agency must report on why the previous CAP have failed and how they
plan to bring this into compliance.
DHHS Policy 722-06B - page 2-6 - Family Team Meetings.
13

Six of eight foster care files and three of three independent living files were found
to be have missing FTMs, and/or late FTMs, and/or not uploaded FTM reports.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 10/15/19, and corresponding CAP,
11/13/19 and Renewal Report, 08/01/18, and corresponding CAP, 08/15/18.
Special investigation 2020C0207003, dated 04/06/20, and corresponding
CAP, dated 04/16/20. The agency must report on why the previous CAP have
failed and how they plan to bring this into compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-03C OLDER YOUTH: PREPARATION, PLACEMENT,
AND DISCHARGE, p 1-2 Life Skills Assessment
Three of three independent living youth did not have Casey Life Skills
Assessments in the records.
DHHS Policy ADM 870 – Page 1- Denial of MCI Consent to Adopt a Specific
Child
Two of two adoptive family files reviewed for denials were noncompliant as one file
did not contain the required denial letter (605) and the other contained an unsigned
copy of the denial letter in MiSACWIS that was uploaded 2 months after the date
on document.
DHHS Policy ADM 300, DHHS 1927 – CHILD ADOPTION ASSESSMENT
One of three child adoption assessments was completed days late.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 234
The agency was directed to review with their DCWL Central Office Consultant how
to address a foster home with an empty pool and empty hot tub.
R 325
The agency was advised that the timeframes noted in the CAPs for foster homes
need to be monitored for timely completion and addressed accordingly if not. It was
noted that some were not met per the CAP deadline, but were completed prior to 6
months as the rule requires. The agency should ensure documentation of follow up
related to the CAP timeframes.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R 327
The agency was advised that they should include the special evaluation number of
14

previous investigations if referenced in other special evaluation reports or
reevaluation reports. It makes it cleaner and easier to track.
The agency was advised that observations were made of delays in supervisory
signatures on various documents. It was recommended that consistency be applied
in terms of supervisory signatures on documents.
15

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This is a decrease from three in the previous inspection. The agency opened a
special investigation of this foster home and worked collaboratively with DHHS to
investigate the complaint and address the actions of the foster parents.
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
One CAP, dated 04/16/20, was submitted in response to special investigation
2020C0207003, dated 04/06/20. This investigation resulted in five violations as
follows: three sections of R 418, FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings, and FOM
722-10 Court Hearing Notification Requirements. Family Team Meetings was cited
in this inspection, thereby finding the agency CAP is not working to address the
noncompliance.
One CAP, dated 02/28/20, was submitted in response to special investigation
2020C0207006, dated 02/14/20. A violation was noted for R 413 which was not
found in this inspection. This indicates the agency is following their CAP and it has
been successful in addressing the issue.
There were 35 violations noted in the last inspection, 17 of which were repeat
violations. There are 33 in this inspection, 17 of which had one or more parts that
were repeat non-compliances. Of these, it was observed that significant
improvement was made in timeliness of case service plans and timeliness of social
work contact entries. Overall, the records were better updated as well, although it
appeared that not all information is being uploaded timely. Additionally, it is notable
that seven violations were for one isolated case or one isolated instance of non-
compliance which is also showing improvement in consistency. It is advisable that
the agency focus on the repeat violations and develop robust corrective measures
with significant oversight to ensure they are brought into compliance during the next
period to avoid potential licensing action.
The field analyst reported no safety concerns or alerts during their home visits.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
16

July 23, 2020
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 23, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
17
